nodes.text: So far, these Trickster reports have been most interesting. I'm pleased that you all took this assignment seriously.
Herr Sosi - your report on Mercurius as the Trickster god of Sicilia was most thorough.
Of course, Master. Mercurius is the patron god of my family.
(whispered) A god of Thieves and Merchants... I can see why Sosi would like Mercurius.
Fräulein MacMichael, you make an excellent point that a Monkey should be considered the sailor's Trickster. I was unaware that sailors often had monkeys as pets.
My father had a monkey named 'Chichi' on his ship. He'd bring it home when he was on holiday and it always made a mess of everything.
Fräulein Esme, the stories you tell about Rover Davy are fascinating... perhaps one day, you should write a book recording such tales.
Thank you, sir.
Reynard the Fox was a good subject for your report, Herr Kent. Despite your deceptively studious manner, I suspect there's a great deal of mischief within your soul.
I'd like to think so, sir.
Your choice of the Raven Trickster was appropriate for you, Herr Kyro. Perhaps you, too, will learn to soar above your current status.
I will do my best, Master.
So now we come to Herr O'Conner. I hope you will demonstrate as much diligence and thought with your report as your compatriots have done.
I did some research on Till Eulenspiegel of Germania...
Till Eulenspiegel mocked the pompous, the arrogant, and the hypocrites with his pranks and practical jokes. He was very much a Rogue.
I did some research on the Trickster of my heritage - the Leprechaun...
Sehr gut, Herr O'Conner. The people of Eire have always had a fondness for Tricksters.
I did my research on the role of Tricksters in society...
While the assignment was to research a specific Trickster rather than lecture on their role, I will credit you for the thoroughness of your presentation.
I talked to Chef Kinah about the Spider Trickster, Anansi...
An interesting tale well told. Clearly Chef Kinah is a good source of esoteric information.
I talked to you, Master von Urwald, about Foxes and Rogues...
You tell such stories very well, Herr O'Conner.

options.text: Admit that You Didn't Do Your Homework

nodes.text: There's been so much going on around here that I was distracted and forgot all about it until after the library had closed.
It's interesting to note that your fellow classmates have all the same sorts of distractions, yet they somehow managed to pull off this assignment with panache.
Of all the Tricksters in myth, story and song, the sneakiest, cleverest, and the most cunning is the Rogue...
It seems that you, Herr O'Conner, have learned the lesson of the Trickster well.
A poor attempt at improvisation on your part, Herr O'Conner. You should have done your homework.

options.text: Bluff About the Purpose of the Lesson

nodes.text: It seems to me that the whole point of this lesson is that we Rogues are all Tricksters...
You make your points well. Yes, Rogues are the Tricksters of modern society.
And you are clearly a Trickster if you think you can get away without doing your class assignment.
Your bravado does not disguise the fact that you failed to research the topic. Gall is not a substitute for proper preparation.
I remind you all that we are approaching the end of the semester. Think about what you have done and who has earned the title of Rogue of the Year.
You will be judged on your actions in and out of the classroom. You will also have a chance to rate your fellow students as to how well you think that they deserve this reward.
The Final Rogue Test will be next week, so you should avoid distractions and actually study for a change. It would be a pity to flunk this class after all you've been through here.
Good afternoon.
